column25: The recent issue I find frustrating with Weverse is the lives. When I first joined, there wasn‚Äôt an option for instant translation during live streams, and we had to wait hours or even days for a translation. Recently, Weverse added an auto-translate feature but it comes at a price.  It feels like the focus isn‚Äôt really on connecting idols with fans anymore, but rather on finding ways to make money from fans everywhere.

column21: I think the idol themselves are a brand and product, as much as they are also simply a human being. They're doing a job and they're good at it, so a lot of the perception and brand influence of them being a brand ambassador doesn't really work on me at a personal level. I'm more reliant on peer reviews and brand reviews on shopping and employee sites than the actual fans of the idols themselves. E.g., even though I'm a big fan of Mingyu from SVT ‚Äì I don't purchase what he endorses, because I know the products he's pushing aren't going to work for me. I also refuse to purchase all HYBE merch, because I know there's a marketing reason behind it.

column25: many things are behind expensive paywalls like subscriptions, and the push to integrate into one platform only like weverse - or other groups developing their own app to compete like JYP‚Äôs Fans(? and it becomes too much on your phone‚Äôs storage. Also the way some notices/events or new music promotions aren‚Äôt broadcasted on all of the group‚Äôs social media platforms. I don‚Äôt want to exit an app just to read an annoucement of an enlistment, and then switch apps again for better fellow fans interactions/reactions to the news (simply due to regulations and censorship as well bc Kr cyber laws vs US cyber laws). Switching apps is annoying bc for most ppl weverse then becomes a single use app, so inconvenient.
